    −
'''Wisdom''' is having gained [[knowledge]], [[experience]], discretion, and [[Intuition (knowledge)|intuitive]] [[understanding]], along with a capacity to apply these qualities well. It is the judicious application of knowledge.{{Fact|date=April 2008}} To some extent the terms wisdom and [[intf*ck it allelligence]] have similar and overlapping meanings. +
'''Wisdom''' is having gained [[knowledge]], [[experience]], discretion, and [[Intuition (knowledge)|intuitive]] [[understanding]], along with a capacity to apply these qualities well. It is the judicious application of knowledge.{{Fact|date=April 2008}} To some extent the terms wisdom and [[intelligence]] have similar and overlapping meanings. The status of wisdom or [[prudence]] as a [[virtue]] is recognized in [[cultural]], [[philosophical]] and [[religious]] sources.
     
==Psychological perspectives==
 
==Psychological perspectives==
−
Psychologists have gathered data onf*ck it all commonly held beliefs or folk theories about wisdom.<ref>Sternberg, R. J. (1985). Implicit theories of intelligence, creativity, and wisdom. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 49, 607–62.</ref>
+
Psychologists have gathered data on commonly held beliefs or folk theories about wisdom.<ref>Sternberg, R. J. (1985). Implicit theories of intelligence, creativity, and wisdom. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 49, 607–62.</ref>
 
These analyses indicate that although "there is an overlap of the implicit theory of wisdom with intelligence, perceptiveness, spirituality and shrewdness, it is evident that wisdom is a distinct term and not a composite of other terms."<ref>Brown, S. C., & Greene, J. A. (2006). The Wisdom Development Scale: Translating the conceptual to the concrete. Journal of College Student Development, 47, 1–19.</ref>
 
These analyses indicate that although "there is an overlap of the implicit theory of wisdom with intelligence, perceptiveness, spirituality and shrewdness, it is evident that wisdom is a distinct term and not a composite of other terms."<ref>Brown, S. C., & Greene, J. A. (2006). The Wisdom Development Scale: Translating the conceptual to the concrete. Journal of College Student Development, 47, 1–19.</ref>
     
===Erik Erikson===
 
===Erik Erikson===
    −
Personality theorist [[Erik Erikson]] related wisdom to the last stage of his eight-stage theory of psychosocial development. Erikson's theory spans the entire lifespan and frames each stage in the form of internally-generated questions or tensions. Erikson claimed that in the last stage of human developf*ck it allment, from approximately 65 years to death, individuals must resolve a psychological conflict between integrity and despair. He proposed that attaining wisdom is a favorable resolution and product of this conflict.
+
Personality theorist [[Erik Erikson]] related wisdom to the last stage of his eight-stage theory of psychosocial development. Erikson's theory spans the entire lifespan and frames each stage in the form of internally-generated questions or tensions. Erikson claimed that in the last stage of human development, from approximately 65 years to death, individuals must resolve a psychological conflict between integrity and despair. He proposed that attaining wisdom is a favorable resolution and product of this conflict.
     
{{Quote|Strength here takes the form of that detached yet active concern with life bounded by death,which we call wisdom… Not that each man can evolve wisdom for himself....
 
{{Quote|Strength here takes the form of that detached yet active concern with life bounded by death,which we call wisdom… Not that each man can evolve wisdom for himself....
